info.game_comments:
Dan Melia game 2.
First game of Season 14 (1997-1998).
First season to offer a car as a bonus prize to all 5-time undefeated champs.
New theme and "Think!" music.  Microphones on contestants' podiums removed.

(1, 1).clue: In a 1996 film Leonardo DiCaprio & Claire Danes play these star-crossed lovers in a modern setting

(2, 1).clue: In "Julius Caesar" Casca says, "For mine own part, it was" this "to me"

(3, 1).clue: Promising more assertiveness, John Sweeney was elected president of this labor federation in 1995

(4, 1).clue: Indonesia's Mount Marapi, whose name means "fire mountain", is one of these

(5, 1).clue: In March 1997 Clinton & Yeltsin agreed to disagree on the expansion of this defense organization

(6, 1).clue: In 1983 he said, "We at Chrysler borrow money the old-fashioned way.  We pay it back"

(1, 2).clue: This shock jock exposed his "Private Parts" in a recent film based on his autobiography

(2, 2).clue: Glossolalia, nonmeaningful speech, is also called speaking in these

(3, 2).clue: In 1969 the brakemen, firemen & switchmen on these were "tied" together in one union

(4, 2).clue: As the highest peak, 4,000-foot Ataviros could be called the colossus of this Greek island

(5, 2).clue: In 1989 this president met Gorbachev on a ship in the "Seasick Summit"

(6, 2).clue: Attributed to Samuel Goldwyn: "Any man who goes to" one of these people "ought to have his head examined"

(1, 3).clue: In this 1993 film, Holly Hunter performed the musical sequences herself

(2, 3).clue: Unclear bureaucratic talk; it's not talking turkey, but sounding like one

(3, 3).clue: OCAW is the union of oil, chemical & these workers; let's hope Homer Simpson's not a member

(4, 3).clue: The wind-blocking Panamint Range helps keep this lowest area of the U.S. hot & dry

(5, 3).clue: Jimmy Carter invited Begin & Sadat to talk peace at this Maryland retreat & they acted accordingly

(6, 3).clue: "Touch a scientist and you touch a child", said this "Martian Chronicles" author

(1, 4).clue: Letter perfect names of the 2 characters seen here:"I don't suppose you know what kind of alien life form leaves a green spectral trail and craves sugar water, do you?""Oh, wait.  That was on Final Jeopardy! last night!"

(2, 4).clue: People had a tough time figuring out exactly what the lyrics were to this 1963 Kingsmen hit

(3, 4).clue: This worker may be found on an airplane or as a union representative on a shop floor

(4, 4).clue: The names Mont Blanc & the Rockies' Blanca Peak both mean this

(5, 4).clue: A 1961 JFK-Khrushchev summit ended in an agreement on this neighbor of Vietnam & Cambodia

(6, 4).clue: John Buchan defined this kind of skeptic as "a man who has no invisible means of support"

(1, 5).clue: In this 1991 satire, Sally Field played the star of a daytime serial, "The Sun Also Sets"

(2, 5).clue: Specialized language of a profession or trade that's meaningless to those outside the field

(3, 5).clue: In 1995 the Int'l Association of Machinists staged a 69-day strike against this Seattle-based company

(5, 5).clue: In 1945 Truman conferred with Stalin & with British leaders Churchill & Attlee at this Berlin suburb

(6, 5).clue: P.G. Wodehouse defined it as the "only one real cure for grey hair.  It was invented by a Frenchman"

(1, 1).clue: In 1961 the Washington Senators moved to Bloomington & became this A.L. team

(2, 1).clue: An astronomical unit is defined as the average distance between these 2 bodies

(3, 1).clue: This was Bonnie Bedelia's original last name; she's Macaulay's aunt

(4, 1).clue: The title character in this classic came into the world as James Gatz

(5, 1).clue: In the 1550s this artist & sculptor was architect for the Palazzo Farnese

(6, 1).clue: In Shakespeare, the 5 words that precede "And all the men and women merely players"

(1, 2).clue: A state nickname was derived from a cartoon in which railroad promoters were likened to these pesky rodents

(2, 2).clue: At standard pressure it's the boiling point of water on the Fahrenheit scale

(3, 2).clue: Here's "The Naked Truth"; she was born with the last name Pantleoni

(4, 2).clue: She started sleuthing in 1930 & in 1991 solved her 100th mystery

(5, 2).clue: First name shared by French artists Toulouse-Lautrec & Matisse

(6, 2).clue: It was not called just the Pretty Good War, but the Great War

(1, 3).clue: Minnesota's lowest point is 602 feet above sea level at the shore of this Great Lake

(2, 3).clue: This small letter denotes the speed of light in a vacuum:  299,792,458 meters per second

(3, 3).clue: Her name was Holly Michelle Gilliam before she married Papa John & became a singing Mama

(4, 3).clue: Arkady Renko, a Moscow investigator in this author's "Gorky Park", becomes a seaman in "Polar Star"

(5, 3).clue: Out of favor with the leftists in Mexico, he created murals in the U.S., like one in the Detroit Inst. of Arts

(6, 3).clue: The domain of Hades, brother of Zeus & Poseidon

(1, 4).clue: A Duluth park named for this Norseman features a replica of the ship in which he sailed to America c. 1000

(2, 4).clue: The acceleration of this at the Earth's surface is 9.8 meters per second squared

(3, 4).clue: Born Lawrence Harvey Zeiger, he became the "monarch" of TV interviewers

(4, 4).clue: "Treasure" & "Raise The Titanic" by this author feature salvage expert Dirk Pitt

(5, 4).clue: "The Hay Wain" helped this British landscape artist win a gold medal at the Paris Salon of 1824

(2, 5).clue: F is 96,500 coulombs; F being named for this British physicist

(3, 5).clue: Professional name of the punk rocker born James Jewel Osterberg; it sounds like a weird soft drink

(4, 5).clue: She had "Great Expectations" until she was jilted on her wedding day

(5, 5).clue: They shut the lid on this Dutch master after his death, March 19, 1997

(0, 0).clue: At this man's death in 1997, Jacques Chirac called him probably the best known Frenchman in the world
